The relationship between food systems and climate change is bi-directional, and climate change is currently affecting yields of crops and livestock products and is projected to continue to do so in the future ***#b13***">[15,#b14">16].</ns0:s>
While these processes also determine grain quality, climatic variability is likely to affect the nutritional quality of other crop groups ***#b1***">(Alae-Carew et al., 2020).</ns0:s>

Thus, any slight variations in weather conditions affect yield negatively. Fruits are typically more vulnerable to weather extremes, such as high temperatures and soil moisture stress, which cause the crops to shrivel and their leaves to turn yellow ***#b30***">[31,#b31">32].</ns0:s>

While the impacts of climate change on such crops have been widely studied, the impacts on specialty crops, like tree fruit, are less clear (Manners and van Etten 2018***#b3***">, Alae-Carew et al 2020, Leisner 2020, Kerr et al 2022).</ns0:s>
Negative impacts of climate change have also been registered in the production of cotton #b6">[6], oilseeds #b7">[7], fruits, nuts, and seeds ***#b8***">[8].</ns0:s>

However, the impact on developing countries with limited resources and weak health systems will be more obvious #b15">[16]***#b16***">[17]#b17">[18]#b18">[19]#b19">[20].</ns0:s>

The vulnerability framework proposed by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) in its Third #b50">(IPCC 2001) and Fourth #b51">(IPCC 2007) Assessment Reports (TAR and AR4,respectively) is widely used in climate-related vulnerability assessments #b76">(Nguyen et al. 2016#b77">(Nguyen et al. , 2017;;***#b13***">Crane et al. 2017;#b6">Aslam et al. 2018;#b28">Filho et al. 2018;#b31">Foden et al. 2019).</ns0:s>

Some reviews have focused on indicators of vulnerability and their role in the science-policy interface #b47">(Hinkel 2011;#b97">Tonmoy et al. 2014;#b76">Nguyen et al. 2016), as well as on the sectoral and geographical applications of vulnerability assessments [e.g., social #b16">(Cutter 2003;#b77">Nguyen et al. 2017), livelihood #b44">(Hahn et al. 2009), urban #b28">(Filho et al. 2018) and coastal #b76">(Nguyen et al. 2016) regions, groundwater #b6">(Aslam et al. 2018), biodiversity #b31">(Foden et al. 2019;#b81">Pacifici et al. 2015), agriculture ***#b13***">(Crane et al. 2017;#b27">Fellmann 2012), and forestry #b26">(FAO 2018)].</ns0:s>

For example, some studies have noted that the IPCC's revised vulnerability concept has received little attention #b9">(Borges et al. 2019;#b31">Foden et al. 2019) and that the TAR/AR4 vulnerability concept continues to predominate #b82">(Pinnegar et al. 2019;#b95">Timberlake and Schultz 2019) and to be used across vulnerability studies #b76">(Nguyen et al. 2016;***#b13***">Crane et al. 2017;#b28">Filho et al. 2018;#b6">Aslam et al. 2018).</ns0:s>

Vulnerability is a multidimensional #b33">[35], complex, dynamic #b34">[36], and context-specific ***#b35***">[37] phenomenon that changes in space and time and is rooted in past conditions #b34">[36].</ns0:s>

Measuring vulnerability is notoriously challenging as assessments suppose theoretically specified connections or linkages between often non-observable elements ***#b17***">(Crane et al., 2017).</ns0:s>

These non-observable elements are assumed to constitute vulnerability, supported by theoretical models that are then measured through sets of proxy indicators ***#b17***">(Crane et al., 2017;#b33">Hinkel, 2011;#b80">Tonmoy et al., 2014;#b84">Vincent & Cull, 2014).</ns0:s>
Assessing vulnerability entails the operationalization of the vulnerability frameworks selected ***#b17***">(Crane et al., 2017;#b33">Hinkel, 2011).</ns0:s>

Indicators are commonly used to operationalize vulnerability, either deductively, based on theoretical frameworks, or inductively based on data used to build statistical models, or using a normative approach based on (individual or collective) value judgments ***#b17***">(Crane et al., 2017;#b33">Hinkel, 2011;#b80">Tonmoy et al., 2014;#b84">Vincent & Cull, 2014).</ns0:s>

The Vulnerability Patterns framework is similar to the IPCC framework, but provides a considerable elaboration of adaptive capacity, specifically on coping capacity to adjust to climate-related risks, manage loss and damage or explore alternative opportunities ***#b17***">(Crane et al., 2017).</ns0:s>

This framework applies the cluster analysis methodology as a way to deliver useful insights into recurrent combinations of measurements based on similarities among systems of analysis, in cases where such a clustering exists ***#b17***">(Crane et al., 2017;#b39">Kok et al., 2016;#b69">Sietz et al., 2011).</ns0:s>

The sensitivity of pastoral farming and other agricultural activities to changes in climatic variability and extremes have been well documented ***#b47***">(Crane et al. 2017, Cradock-Henry et al. 2019a#b74">, George et al. 2019).</ns0:s>
